answers: Drosophila melanogaster [or common fruit fly or vinegar fly; accept just Drosophila]
Saccharomyces cerevisiae [or baker's yeast; accept just Saccharomyces]
Aplysia californica [or California sea slug; or California sea hare]
parts: Charles Woodworth was an early geneticist who studied this species of Diptera. These insects have four chromosomes, bar-eyes, and antennapedia.
This species of yeast has been used to study aging and brew beer. They can switch between A and alpha mating types, and they were used by Hartwell to study cell division.
This genus of molluscs is used to study the nervous system. Eric Kandel studied the gill withdrawal reflex in this organism

answers: monopolies [or trusts; do not accept or prompt on "oligopoly"]
marginal cost [or marginal expenditure; prompt on cost; prompt on expenditure; do not accept "average cost"]
infinity [or negative infinity; or perfectly elastic]
parts: Name these firms, who control so much of a market that they are price-setters rather than price-takers.
Monopolies are able to profit at the expense of consumers because they set the price above this value. This value is the money spent on producing an additional unit of the good being sold.

Unlike a monopoly, a perfectly competitive firm faces a demand curve with this value for its price elasticity. For goods of this elasticity, any increase in price will result in quantity demanded becoming zero.

answers: Scotland [or Alba; accept Scottish Fantasy; accept Scottish Symphony; do not accept or prompt on "Britain"]
parts: Name this German Romantic composer of Kol Nidrei who is best remembered for his Violin Concerto No. 1 in G Minor.
Another German composer of the Romantic period was this man who composed the oratorio Elijah, incidental music for A Midsummer Night's Dream, and the collection Songs Without Words.

Both Bruch and Mendelssohn created pieces named after this country. Bruch's work is a fantasy in E-flat major for violin and orchestra, while Mendelssohn's is a symphony that was written on the same trip that also produced his Hebrides Overture.

answers: the Prix Goncourt [or the Goncourt Prize]
Marcel Proust [or Valentin Louis Georges EugÃ¨ne Marcel Proust]
parts: Name this French literary award given yearly to promising beginning authors, named for the brothers Jules and Edmond. It was controversially not awarded to Louis-Ferdinand Celine in 1932.
This author of Against Sainte-Beuve won the 1919 Prix Goncourt for the novel Within a Budding Grove, the third volume of his sprawling seven-part novel In Search of Lost Time.

Swann's Way, the first volume of Proust's In Search of Lost Time, was initially rejected for publication by this author of The Immoralist, who wrote of Olivier's affairs with the Comte de Passavant and his uncle Edouard in The Counterfeiters.

answers: electric field [do NOT accept electromagnetic field, as that is wrong]
permittivity of free space [or electric permittivity; prompt on epsilon or epsilon naught]
the speed of light [prompt on c]
parts: Identify this vector field created by charged particles. It can be computed using Gauss' and Coulomb's laws.
Coulomb's law contains a constant factor equal to one over 4 pi times this constant. Its absolute form in a dielectric material can be computed from the electric susceptibility.
One over the square root of electric permittivity times magnetic permeability equals this constant. This fact led Maxwell to formulate his theory of electromagnetic radiation.

answers: Alexander the Great [or Alexander III of Macedon]
parts: This musician's wife was killed by a snake bite. When he descended to the Underworld, he lost her forever by looking back.
This wife of Cadmus was transformed into a snake in her old age. Hephaestus gave her a namesake cursed necklace at her wedding.

Plutarch says this man was fathered when Zeus slept with Olympias in the form of a snake. This pagan member of the Nine Worthies gained favor by freeing a bound ox-cart in Phrygia, and his mortal father used the sarissa lance.

answers: Theodosius I [or Theodosius the Great or Flavius Theodosius]
parts: Identify this artifact which allowed Thomas Young and Jean-Francois Champollion to decipher Egyptian hieroglyphics.
The middle portion of the Rosetta Stone was written in this script, a cursive form of hieroglyphics. Coptic is derived from this script.

The Rosetta Stone likely broke off during this Emperor's destruction of non-Christian temples. The death of this victor at the 394 CE Battle of the Frigidus split his Empire between his sons Arcadius and Honorius.

answers: Seikan Tunnel [or Seikan Tonneru; or Seikan Zuido]
parts: This main Japanese island, which includes the cities of Osaka and Tokyo, lies directly south of Hokkaido.
This city on the Ishikari Plain, which straddles the Toyohira River, is Hokkaido's capital. It hosted the 1972 Winter Olympics.
This tunnel beneath the Tsugaru Strait connects the city of Hakodate (ha-koh-DAH-tay) on Hokkaido to Aomori on Honshu. Opened in 1988, this is the deepest and longest active rail tunnel in the world.

answers: Port Royal Experiment [or Sea Islands Experiment]
Freedmen's Bureau [or Bureau of Refugees, Freedmen, and Abandoned Lands]
parts: Freed slaves were given abandoned plantation lands and helped by Mansfield French's American Missionary Association in this experimental program, named for the South Carolina port seized by the Union in November 1861.
This agency led by Oliver Howard was created to help former slaves find jobs and to guarantee fair treatment of black employees in the south.
William T. Sherman's Special Field Order 15 gave freed blacks this amount of land. This amount is often paired with a certain beast of burden, though it was never part of Sherman's order.

answers: "Thirteen Ways of Looking at a Blackbird"
parts: he" title creature "is involved in what I know." For 10 points each: [10] Name this Wallace Stevens poem which presents several views of an animal whose eye was "among twenty snowy mountains, the only moving thing."
Wallace Stevens once broke his hand in a fight with this author of The Old Man and the Sea.

This Stevens poem repeatedly alludes to the Biblical story of Susanna and claims that "beauty is momentary in the mind" but "in the flesh it is immortal". Its first section describes its how its speaker's "fingers on these keys make music".
Name this metallurgical process of extracting metals, partly named for the fact that it occurs at high temperatures
The inputs to smelting are these rocks, which contain a metal that one wishes to extract. Cinnabar is one of these rocks for mercury.
One chemical often used as a reducing agent in smelting is this one, which is made from coal. Cracking is used to produce its petroleum equivalent.

answers: The Nobel Prize in Literature [or Nobelpriset i litteratur; or the Literature Nobel; prompt on less specific answers like "the Nobel Prize"]
parts: Identify this author of The Republic of Wine, who described a constantly-reincarnating farmer in Life and Death Are Wearing Me Out and debuted with the five-volume novel Red Sorghum.
Mo Yan is, as of June 2013, the most recent winner of this major prize awarded by the Swedish Academy, a position in which he was preceded by Tomas Transtromer in 2011 and Mario Vargas Llosa in 2010.

This 1967 winner of the Nobel in Literature explored the conflict between commercial farmers and indigenous Guatemalans in Men of Maize. Miguel Angel Face advises the title dictator in his novel El SeÃ±or Presidente.

answers: The Passion of Joan of Arc [or La Passion de Jeanne d'Arc]
silent films [prompt on answers like films without sound, since they do sort of have sound]
Nosferatu, eine Symphonie des Grauens [or Nosferatu, a Symphony of Horror]
parts: Name this Carl Dreyer film in which Renee Falconetti stars as the title short-haired woman, who is coerced into signing a confession and is burned at the stake soon after.

The Passion of Joan of Arc is one of the best-known films of this kind, which made heavy use of title cards and mimery. Lillian Gish and Charlie Chaplin starred in films of this kind, which went out of popularity with the advent of the "talkie."
Another film directed by Dreyer is Vampyr, which is often compared to this F.W. Murnau expressionist classic starring Max Schreck as the vampire Count Orlok.

answers: Indira Priyadarshini Gandhi [or Indira Priyadarshini Nehru; prompt on partial answer]
forced sterilization [or compulsory sterilization; specifically accept forced vasectomies; accept forced chemical castration]
parts: Identify this Prime Minister who was killed after ordering the controversial Operation Blue Star in 1984.
Indira Gandhi was assassinated by bodyguards of this faith in response to the attack on the Golden Temple at Amritsar. Members of this faith are the majority in India's region of Punjab.

Both Indira and Sanjay Gandhi promoted this controversial practice, which the Shah Commision revealed was made mandatory for rickshaw drivers seeking a new license. This practice was the subject of the Supreme Court case Stump v. Sparkman.
Name these aqueous analogues of dust devils and twisters.
Waterspouts and twisters are characteristic phenomena of these kinds of thunderstorms, which feature a mesocyclone

Supercells may accompany this other weather phenomenon, a sudden increase in wind speed that often occurs in conjunction with a thunderstorm. Its namesake line consists of a stretch of severe weather in front of a cold front.

answers: Nero [or Nero Claudius Caesar Augustus Germanicus or Nero Claudius Drusus Germanicus or Lucius Domitius Ahenobarbus]
parts: Identify this failed conspiracy. Lucan and Seneca committed suicide after this plot was foiled.
The Pisonian Conspiracy targeted this Roman Emperor, who was accused of fiddling during the Great Fire of Rome.
After the Great Fire, Nero constructed the opulent Domus Aurea on this hill in Rome. Romulus and Remus were legendarily suckled by the she-wolf on this hill.

answers: The Green Christ [or Breton Calvary; or The Calvary; or Le Christ vert]
parts: Name this French post-impressionist painter who drew upon his experiences in Tahiti and the rest of the south seas to paint works like Where do we come from? What are we? Where are we going?
In his painting Vision After the Sermon, Gauguin depicted this biblical character. A group of Breton women observe and pray as he wrestles with an angel.
In this Gauguin painting, the coast of Brittany can be seen in the background as a woman sits beneath a statue of Jesus being lifted down from the cross.
Name this pacifist Christian sect which emerged in 17th-century Britain. William Penn established a colony for its adherents called Pennsylvania.
This British religious reformer started Quakerism, recounting his experiences in a posthumously-published journal.
Many Quakers adhere to this theological position, the belief that all people will reach heaven.

Identify this man who defended the fantastical elements of the title epic poem in his essay, "Beowulf: The Monsters and the Critics". A posthumously-published mythological work by this author begins with the section "AinulindalÃ«" and was completed by his son Christopher.
Tolkien's devout Catholicism helped spur the conversion of this fellow member of the Inklings. This author's works include the Space Trilogy, The Screwtape Letters, and The Chronicles of Narnia.

Tolkien once translated this poem, found on a manuscript along with works like "Patience" and "Purity", which begins and ends with a man in an "erber grene". Its namesake anonymous poet probably also wrote Sir Gawain and the Green Knight.

answers: Nazi Party [or National Socialist German Worker's Party; or  Nationalsozialistische Deutsche Arbeiterpartei]
parts: Name this postmodern approach to criticizing texts and social structures. It was pioneered in Jacques Derrida's Of Grammatology.
This political party was praised in articles by deconstructionist Paul de Man in the 40s. Its founding text was Mein Kampf.

This field, the study of signs and symbols, inspired many post-structuralist approaches to criticism. Roland Barthes was in this field, whose tenets include Saussure's divide between the signifier and signified.
The fifth version of this language includes support for a canvas element in an attempt to supplant Flash. Basic webpages created using this markup language consist of a head and a body tag.
Attributes of a webpage like the font size and background color are often specified in these files, which contain a list of property and value pairs attached to a selector.
CSS selectors beginning with a period match this type of attribute. Setting this attribute to a common value on different HTML elements provides a way to style those elements the same.

answers: Weimar Republic [or Weimarer Republik or Weimar Germany; prompt on just "Germany"]
Paul von Hindenburg [or Paul Ludwig Hans Anton von Beneckendorff und von Hindenburg]
parts: Identify this government whose leaders included Joseph Wirth and Foreign Minister Walter Rathenau.

Rathenau signed this 1922 treaty with Georg Chicherin of the Soviet Union. It normalized relationships between the two nations, and may have been signed to facilitate a secret joint chemical weapons effort.
This former field marshal served as president of the Weimar Republic from 1925 until 1935. Aided by Max Hoffman and Erich Ludendorff, this man won the Battle of Tannenberg in 1914.

answers: Thomakin [or Thomas or Tomakin; prompt on "The Director"]
parts: Identify this author who took a phrase from Milton's Samson Agonistes to title his novel about Anthony Beavis, Eyeless in Gaza. He also recounted a mescaline trip in his book The Doors of Perception.
Aldous Huxley's most famous work is this dystopian novel, which opens in the year 632 After Ford and focuses primarily on Bernard Marx and John the Savage.
This character from Brave New World resigns his position as Director of the Hatcheries after it is revealed that he fathered John the Savage in New Mexico.
